author: By Troy Closson
title: Pain Doctor Found Guilty of Sexually Assaulting Patients
description: Ricardo Cruciani was known as a gifted neurologist. But Manhattan prosecutors said he took advantage of his patients’ chronic pain.
content: For more than a decade, Ricardo Cruciani built a reputation as a gifted and esteemed physician who could relieve chronic pain when other doctors could not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Conductor Who Knows His Way Around a Score, and a Farm
description: Santtu-Matias Rouvali, a contender for the podium at the New York Philharmonic, spends as much free time as possible at home in rural Finland.
content: YLÖJÄRVI, Finland — “Here I grow peas,” the conductor Santtu-Matias Rouvali said, gesturing to a plot of land the size of a small room. “Why? I just love fresh peas.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Speaks to Russia’s Foreign Minister, Seeking Deal for Griner and Whelan
description: Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, declined to say how his Russian counterpart responded as he continued to seek the release of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke on Friday to his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, and urged him to accept a proposal for the release of Brittney Griner and Paul N. Whelan, but reported no breakthrough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn
title: Climate Bill ‘Transformative’ for Auto and Energy Industries
description: The Senate’s proposal aims to accelerate electric car sales and promote domestic battery manufacturing at China’s expense.
content: The $369 billion climate and tax package Democrats in the Senate proposed this week could have far-reaching effects on the kinds of cars that Americans drive, where those cars are made and how the country produces its energy. The legislation also aims to break China’s hold on battery supply chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 5 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 16.
content: Welcome to Week Eight of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Reversing a Reversal, Miami School Board Accepts Sex Ed Books It Had Rejected
description: The decision, part of a battle over school curriculums in Florida and elsewhere, saved students in Miami-Dade County from going months without sex education.
content: The Miami-Dade County School Board reversed itself yet again on Thursday, voting to approve health and sex education textbooks for middle and high school students that have moved to the forefront of Florida’s battle over what is taught in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How is monkeypox spread?
description: The monkeypox virus can spread from person to person through close physical contact with infectious lesions or pustules, by touching items — like clothing or bedding — that previously touched the rash, or via the respiratory droplets produced by coughing or sneezing.
content: The monkeypox virus can spread from person to person through close physical contact with infectious lesions or pustules, by touching items — like clothing or bedding — that previously touched the rash, or via the respiratory droplets produced by coughing or sneezing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: The S&P 500 had its best month since November 2020.
description: The rebound in stocks is a reflection that the current round of updates from corporate America are not as bad as feared. But there are still reasons for investors to be wary.
content: July turned out to be the best month for Wall Street’s stock investors since November 2020, a rally fueled by better than expected financial results from some of America’s biggest companies and bets that the Federal Reserve could curtail its policy of constraining the economy sooner than previously expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: Pay growth and prices picked up, keeping the Fed on track for rate increases.
description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge climbed rapidly in June. Wage and benefit gains are fast, too, separate data showed.
content: Wages, prices and consumer spending all continued to climb, the latest government data showed Friday — fresh evidence that the economy remains resilient amid fear of a recession, but also that inflation is likely to remain a vexing problem for the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: The One Thing You Can Control at Work Is You
description: Express yourself and your identity in a way that is comfortable to you — and do your best to ignore everything else.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad
title: Lebanon says it is investigating Ukraine’s claim that a docked ship contains plundered grain.
description: The Laodicea, a Syrian cargo ship, arrived in Tripoli, Lebanon, on Wednesday carrying nearly 10 tons of wheat and barley.
content: Lebanese authorities said Friday that they were investigating a Ukrainian claim that a Syrian ship under U.S. sanctions that docked in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli was carrying Ukrainian grain stolen by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Kashkari says officials are ‘a long way’ from backing off inflation fight.
description: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said the Fed had more work to do in trying to control price increases.
content: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, suggested on Friday that markets had gotten ahead of themselves in anticipating that the central bank — which has been raising interest rates swiftly this year — would soon begin to back off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: If the Economy Is Shaky, Why Are Company Profits Still Strong?
description: Corporate optimism may seem at odds with the Fed’s grim determination to hold back the economy to get inflation down, but earnings tell a story that other data doesn’t.
content: Consumers are gloomy, the economy is shrinking, the Federal Reserve wants it to keep slowing and economists now say the whole world could be sliding toward recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Motley Skill Set
description: It’s a Robyn Weintraub Themeless Friday™!
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Good news, everyone! We’ve got a brand-new Robyn Weintraub Themeless Friday™ to lead us into the weekend, and I could not be more excited. I adore Ms. Weintraub’s puzzles. She has the right motley skill set for the job: the constructing chops to craft an impeccably clean grid, the razor-sharp wit to write fiendishly clever clues and the unparalleled sense of fun to create a playful and approachable puzzle vibe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The M.M.A. Doctor’s Dilemma: To Stop or Not to Stop the Fight
description: As combat sports grow in popularity, ringside physicians grapple with the precarious ethics of their role.
content: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Late one Saturday evening in June, two men in their 20s stood across from each other, shirtless and swaying, in a mixed martial arts cage in Exhibit Hall B of the Chattanooga Convention Center. The mat was sticky, a dark canvas of blood and foot sweat. Something in the combatants’ eyes made them look both terrifying and terrified, wolflike and rabbitlike at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Targeting ‘Woke Capital’
description: West Virginia’s banning of five big Wall Street banks for doing business with the state is yet another step toward a politicized world of red brands and blue brands.
content: Five big Wall Street firms woke up to a headache yesterday, and the ailment seems to be spreading fast. Riley Moore, the outspoken treasurer of West Virginia, announced that Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, BlackRock, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo were banned from doing business with the state because they had stopped supporting the coal industry, reports The Times’s David Gelles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lux Alptraum
title: Women, the Game Is Rigged. It’s Time We Stop Playing by the Rules.
description: It’s hard to ignore the fact that empowerment feminism hasn’t really delivered on its promises.
content: For most of the 21st century, the feminism that has been in fashion has leaned heavily on the idea of women’s empowerment. Glossy, celebrity-driven rhetoric, peppered with slogans like “nevertheless, she persisted” and reassurances that “girl, you got this,” suggests that if women display competence and strength — or even just “the confidence of a mediocre white man” — we will eventually earn equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Corrigan
title: The Dog Lawyer Doesn’t Care That You Hate Him
description: In defending dogs at all costs, Richard Rosenthal has made a lot of enemies. But his animal clients owe him their lives.
content: The case before the court involved a Rhode Island greyhound named Lexus, accused of killing a Pomeranian in a dog park. The prosecution was asking for the death penalty, and a lawyer for the defense, Richard Rosenthal, was there to stop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Oil giants are pumping billions of dollars into buying their own shares.
description: Some of the companies’ enormous earnings have been reinvested in expanding operations, but a lot of money has also gone toward share buybacks, which primarily reward shareholders.
content: The world’s biggest oil companies are generating record profits, and they’re using a big part of the windfall, worth tens of billions of dollars, to buy back their own shares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Filmmaker Gabriel Gomez Tells Brooklyn Stories
description: He toggles between commercial videos for big fashion brands, and art-house projects on the New York creative class.
content: Name: Gabriel Gomez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Brittney Griner and the Total Lopsidedness of Prisoner Swaps with Russia
description: American citizens should still know that if they are imprisoned in a country with a dubious legal system, the U.S. government will do all it can to get them back.
content: Reports are circulating that the United States is negotiating with Russia to exchange two Americans being held in Russian prisons for a notorious arms dealer serving time in America. The deal is totally lopsided: The two Americans — the basketball star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a security company executive — are not criminals and certainly not remotely comparable to Viktor Bout, a notorious purveyor of arms to terrorists once known as the “Merchant of Death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Happy Life’ Review: Ghosts in the Studio
description: The playwright Kathy Ng imagines a world where mortality, eroticism and Hello Kitty collide in a spirited, if sometimes muddled, contemplation of loneliness and loss.
content: Urban real estate is flush with ghosts. How many people have lived and died alone, in apartments stacked toward the clouds? Cities thrive on fantasies of possibility, but the specter of suffering looms behind every door. Just ask the broker peddling a cleaned-up murder scene on the allure of its fresh lemon scent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Baseball’s Sole Mud Harvester and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Baird, Tricia Fulks Kelley and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘We Need Help’: Death Toll Rises in Devastating Kentucky Flooding
description: Hundreds of stranded residents were rescued by aircraft and boats, Gov. Andy Beshear said. There is more rain in the forecast.
content: HAZARD, Ky. — Shirley Stamper, 74, awoke to the sound of wild banging beneath her house. Floodwaters were swallowing her remote mountain community and Ms. Stamper, along with her mother-in-law, Ethel Stamper, 94, needed to get out, immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Feeling Dismissed? How to Spot ‘Medical Gaslighting’ and What to Do About It.
description: Experts share tips on advocating for yourself in a health care setting.
content: Christina, who lives in Portland, Me., said she felt ignored by doctors for years. When she was 50 pounds heavier, her providers sometimes blamed her body size when she discussed her health concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: I’ll Trade You Some Cursed Baby Dolls and Metal Frogs for That Unwanted Banana Statue
description: John Oliver is willing to make a deal for a piece of (formerly) public art in Fitzroy. That doesn’t mean negotiations have been easy.
content: For the past few months, the British American comedian John Oliver has been locked in talks with the Yarra City Council, in Melbourne, in what has become a labyrinthine negotiation involving public art, vandalism, koala chlamydia, a polystyrene recycling machine, three disturbing giant metal frogs and a bucket full of cursed baby dolls. This past week, the negotiations reached what (I hope) will become a tipping point, because I really want those frogs to be part of my daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Police Seek Help in Deaths of Two Saudi Sisters in Australia
description: Their bodies lay undiscovered for a month. Weeks later, the police still know little about the women or what happened to them.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The case is cloaked in mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: National Park Booking App Leaves Users Feeling Lost in the Woods
description: Little availability for campsites. Confusing booking windows. Traveler and travel industry frustration is growing with Recreation.gov, the online portal to book accommodations and access on federal lands.
content: Aline Prado knew she wanted to visit Glacier National Park during her summer vacation this year. The elementary-school teacher had a monthlong road trip planned with her 8-year-old daughter and three other relatives that would start in their hometown, Houston, and meander through nine national parks and monuments in Wyoming, Montana and Colorado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Russia Is Making Heaps of Money From Oil, but There Is a Way to Stop That
description: Nations seeking to help Ukraine should aim at reducing Russia’s profits from oil, not how much it exports.
content: The United States and its allies are leaning heavily on economic sanctions to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. But a key element in that strategy, restrictions on Russian oil exports, mostly appears to be causing pain for ordinary people in other countries. European nations, in particular, are causing considerable damage to their own economies without reducing Russia’s oil revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chaos Among Spies After the Berlin Wall Crumbles
description: Dan Fesperman talks about his new thriller, “Winter Work,” and Isaac Fitzgerald discusses his memoir, “Dirtbag, Massachusetts.”
content: Dan Fesperman’s 13th thriller, “Winter Work,” is set just after the fall of the Berlin Wall. The Stasi, East Germany’s brutal Cold War intelligence service, was busy destroying evidence. The C.I.A. was just as busy trying to learn the enemy organization’s secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Russian National Charged With Spreading Propaganda Through U.S. Groups
description: Federal authorities say the man recruited several American political groups and used them to sow discord and interfere with elections.
content: MIAMI — The Russian man with a trim beard and patterned T-shirt appeared in a Florida political group’s YouTube livestream in March, less than three weeks after his country had invaded Ukraine, and falsely claimed that what had happened was not an invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Biden Administration Plans to Offer Updated Booster Shots in September
description: With reformulated shots from Pfizer and Moderna on the horizon, the F.D.A. has decided that Americans under 50 should wait to receive second boosters.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration now expects to begin a Covid-19 booster campaign with retooled vaccines in September because Pfizer and Moderna have promised that they can deliver doses by then, according to people familiar with the deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A potential U.S. climate bill.
content: The gross domestic product of the U.S. shrank again, fueling fears of a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Larry Josephson, Champion of Free-Form Radio, Dies at 83
description: His dyspeptic morning show helped make WBAI-FM in New York a vibrant, eccentric, alternative radio haven. “I was the first angry man in morning radio,” he said.
content: Larry Josephson, a cranky practitioner of free-form radio on noncommercial WBAI-FM in New York who helped shape the station into a vibrant, eccentric, alternative radio haven, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michaelangelo Matos
title: Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ Embodies Decades of Dance Music. Here’s a Guide.
description: Chicago house, hyperpop, classic ’70s disco: The pop star’s new album is a tour through some of the genre’s most well-known touchstones as well as more underground sounds.
content: Beyoncé’s new album, “Renaissance,” is consciously steeped in dance-music history, cannily embracing decades of samples and sounds: the 1970s disco of Donna Summer and Chic, Jamaican dancehall, internet-speed hyperpop. She chose collaborators, references and even specific keyboard sounds that pay homage to club-land memories while making her own 21st-century statement. Here are some of the sources she celebrates, and an exploration of their significance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
title: Dry Fountains, Cold Pools, Less Beer? Germans Tiptoe Up the Path to Energy Savings
description: Local leaders find themselves at the front line of Europe’s conservation efforts, fearing a Russian gas cut. It’s not an easy place to be.
content: AUGSBURG, Germany — Wolfgang Hübschle went into city government expecting a simple life, planning things like traditional festivals replete with lederhosen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Pushing an Immigration Conspiracy Theory, While Courting Latinos
description: Blake Masters, a top candidate in Arizona’s Republican primary for the Senate, has accused Democrats of plotting to “import” new voters. That poses a challenge in a state where a third of the voters are Hispanic.
content: Blake Masters, a venture capitalist running for Senate in Arizona, is among the many Republicans who argue that the left’s obsession with racial identity politics is driving Latino voters away from the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How is monkeypox treated?
description: After a diagnosis, monkeypox treatment mainly involves managing symptoms, said Dr. Bernard Camins, the medical director for infection prevention at the Mount Sinai Health System. Patients with anal or rectal lesions may experience a lot of pain, especially while defecating, and in those cases, a doctor may prescribe pain killers or recommend stool softeners and shallow sitz baths, used to relieve pain or itchiness in the genital area, he said. Patients with sores in their mouth may have difficulty swallowing and can use medication to help. Some may develop secondary bacterial infections and require antibiotic treatment, especially if they have large, open lesions.
content: After a diagnosis, monkeypox treatment mainly involves managing symptoms, said Dr. Bernard Camins, the medical director for infection prevention at the Mount Sinai Health System. Patients with anal or rectal lesions may experience a lot of pain, especially while defecating, and in those cases, a doctor may prescribe pain killers or recommend stool softeners and shallow sitz baths, used to relieve pain or itchiness in the genital area, he said. Patients with sores in their mouth may have difficulty swallowing and can use medication to help. Some may develop secondary bacterial infections and require antibiotic treatment, especially if they have large, open lesions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Closes on Broadway as Creators Spar With Rudin
description: The hit play, closed since January, was expected to reopen on Broadway this fall.
content: “To Kill a Mockingbird,” a stage adaptation of the classic novel that in January announced a temporary shutdown after Jeff Daniels left the cast and the Omicron variant slammed into New York, will not reopen on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: To 9/11 Families, Saudi-Backed Golf Event Is ‘Another Atrocity’
description: The families are furious that former President Donald J. Trump once blamed Saudi Arabia for the terrorist attacks, but is now allowing his golf course to be used for its LIV Golf event.
content: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — A somber and tearful group of protesters stood between two American flags behind a public library, in stark contrast to the festivities at a golf tournament three miles down the road. They made their statements and promoted their cause, but declined to take the fight to the gates of Trump National Golf Club Bedminster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Antenna Group Emerges as Bidder for Vice Media
description: Vice Media, which is exploring a sale of its business, has a longstanding relationship with the Greek broadcaster.
content: The Greek broadcaster Antenna is exploring an acquisition of Vice Media, according to three people familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss private negotiations. The deal would consummate a longstanding business relationship between the two companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Large landlords aggressively moved against renters in the pandemic, a report says.
description: A House subcommittee investigation found four firms were responsible for nearly 15,000 eviction filings while there were moratoriums on evictions.
content: A House subcommittee that investigated eviction practices by large landlords during the pandemic issued a scathing report that said four firms had engaged in “abusive” tactics to attempt to push renters out of their homes despite a federal moratorium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez
title: Why Pelosi’s Proposed Taiwan Visit Is Raising U.S.-China Tensions
description: Beijing has issued strongly worded warnings implying that China might use military force if Nancy Pelosi moves forward with a planned trip to Taiwan.
content: Taiwan, an island of 23 million people 80 miles off the coast of China, has long been a point of tension between Washington and Beijing. Now those tensions are at a new high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Going Hiking? Don’t Forget These Safety Tips.
description: Experts say failing to alert family or friends of your plans is one of the biggest mistakes hikers make. Here are some more of their recommendations.
content: The summit on Hawksbill Mountain in Shenandoah National Park in Virginia provides sweeping views of the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Shenandoah Valley. On a clear day, miles of lush forest and valleys can be seen in any direction. It’s the kind of vista that begs for a square on Instagram, isn’t terribly difficult to reach and drives millions to hit the trails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: U.S. Offer to Swap Russian Arms Dealer for Griner Highlights Uncomfortable Choices
description: The negotiations raise questions about what, if any, standards should apply when the United States agrees to trade prisoners.
content: WASHINGTON — One is perhaps the world’s most notorious arms dealer, a man known as the “Merchant of Death” who sold weapons to terrorists, rebels and militants around the world before finally being hunted down and locked up for conspiring to kill Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Michael Crowley and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Griner in Their First Call of the War
description: Ukraine said it was ready for Black Sea grain shipments to resume, while the top Russian and American diplomats talked about a prisoner swap involving the basketball star Brittney Griner.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — The top Russian and American diplomats spoke on Friday for the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, to discuss a possible prisoner swap involving the American basketball star Brittney Griner. Although no breakthrough was reported, it marked a resumption of direct communication between Washington and Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Breaking Agreement to Use a Condom Is a Sex Crime, Canada High Court Rules
description: The Supreme Court ruling is one of the strictest in a recent spate of measures addressing deceptive condom use, as courts try to define consent.
content: TORONTO — It is a crime to renege on a promise to wear a condom during sex without a partner’s knowledge or consent, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The Country That Wants to ‘Be Average’ vs. Jeff Bezos and His $500 Million Yacht
description: Why did Rotterdam stand between one of the world’s richest men and his boat? The furious response is rooted in Dutch values.
content: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands — The image would have been a social media phenomenon: a few thousand citizens of the Netherlands’ second-largest city, standing beside a river and hurling eggs at the gleaming, new 417-foot sailing yacht built for Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and one of the world’s richest men. By the time the boat passed the crowd, it would have been spattered with bright orange yolk, plus at least one very bright spot of red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: A mother was swept up in the rising water. Her son pulled her to safety.
description: Jeannie Adams of Whitesburg, Ky., described a harrowing ordeal after floods engulfed her community. Her home and car were destroyed.
content: On Thursday morning, Jeannie Adams woke before dawn to get ready for work. The yard outside was waterlogged, but this was not unusual; in the 20 years she had lived in a hollow outside Whitesburg, Ky., she had lost count of the number of times she’d had to drive through water to get in and out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Large Video Screen Falls During Mirror Concert in Hong Kong, Injuring 2
description: Two dancers for the popular boy band were hospitalized, a local news outlet reported. Hong Kong officials promised an investigation.
content: The Hong Kong authorities will investigate why a large, heavy video screen fell from the ceiling during a concert by a popular boy band at a government-run venue, injuring two dancers, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Is in Denial
description: It can’t defend the world it has made.
content: It is always painful to grapple with realities that contravene your most deeply held beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: At the Parkland Trial, Families Must Endure Grisly Evidence on Repeat
description: The nature of a death-penalty trial requires documenting brutal crimes in painful detail, even when the defendant’s guilt has never been in doubt.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — To shield heartsick families from the most macabre details of how their loved ones were murdered in a mass school shooting in Parkland, Fla., the court handling the gunman’s sentencing trial has taken an extraordinary step: Graphic videos and photographs are shown only to the jury, so that victims’ relatives and others in the courtroom gallery do not have to endure them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Big Economic Question
description: It is not whether the U.S. is in a recession. It’s whether the economy will soon worsen.
content: The latest G.D.P. numbers — suggesting that the economy shrank in each of the past two quarters — have intensified a debate about whether the U.S. economy has fallen into a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: ‘The Only Woman’ in the Room
description: From journalists to politicians, activists to artists: Centuries’ worth of photos depict women holding their own in a man’s world.
content: “Why her and only her?” the Oscar-nominated documentarian Immy Humes writes in the introduction to THE ONLY WOMAN (Phaidon, $29.95). She is looking at a 1961 photo of the filmmaker Shirley Clarke with her cast and crew, all 22 of them men. “What does her onliness mean?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Does It Really Mean to Live ‘Paycheck to Paycheck’?
description: We don’t have a good agreed-upon definition.
content: There are 17 songs on Napster with the title “Paycheck to Paycheck.” I know because I listened to all of them. (You’re welcome.) These aren’t covers — each has its own lyrics, some pretty good. I like the version by a singer-songwriter named Darrell Bailey because it refers to economists:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Much Ado About Wages
description: Why workers’ pay has become central to inflation debates.
content: At one level, the wages and salaries employers pay their workers are just another price — in this case, the price you pay for the use of someone’s time and effort. If I were a Marxist (which, by the way, I am very much not), I’d say that in a capitalist system, employment becomes commodified, a purely monetary transaction rather than a human relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina, Dan Bilefsky, Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
title: With Russia using energy as leverage, the quest in many parts of Europe is to shrink demand.
description: Germany may be most vulnerable to Russia’s energy squeeze, but many other countries are also facing, at minimum, high prices and restricted supples.
content: In eastern France, a dozen villages have been shutting off their streetlights at midnight. Barcelona is offering home efficiency assessments. Warsaw is subsidizing homes that replace fossil-burning stoves with heat pumps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! My Lost Luggage Wasn’t Delivered for 12 Days. I Want Restitution.
description: After a traveler reads the fine print on the United Airlines website, Tripped Up makes some calls, sends some emails — and gets the traveler $3,000. Our columnist can’t quite believe it.
content: I regularly travel between Houston and Atyrau, Kazakhstan (via Newark and Amsterdam) for work, taking United for the first two legs and Air Astana for the third. The trip is long but the routine is always the same: check your luggage in Texas and pick it up upon arrival. But this past January, United didn’t follow the routine: When I boarded in Newark, I saw on the United app that at least one of my bags had stayed behind. I alerted the flight attendant, who alerted the gate staff, who in turn suggested I get off the plane, get my luggage and fly the next day. But there are limited connections, I had to get to work and I had no idea where my second bag was. (Also lost, it turns out.) Thirteen days and countless calls and letters later, Astana delivered my luggage in Kazakhstan. United eventually offered me $150 in compensation. I believe this is not nearly enough, especially considering their policy on “delayed bags” says I may be eligible for $1,500 per bag if they can’t find my luggage in five days. Can you help? — Laura, Missouri City, Texas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: For Every Season, Weddings, Weddings, Weddings
description: “I think I needed a good kick in the butt to get started on my own.” It’s been a busy year for this wedding florist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Beyoncé’s Anthem for the Unique, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Rosalía, Brian Eno, Robert Glasper and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Dr. Oh, ‘the God of Parenting,’ Will See You Now. On Television.
description: In South Korea, Dr. Oh Eun-young, a celebrated psychiatrist, has helped destigmatize seeking therapy and blown up the traditionally private relationship with patients by putting it all on TV.
content: SEOUL — Appointment day was finally here. The parents had waited for a month to see the renowned psychiatrist in South Korea about their child’s issues. They entered the room, the doctor arrived, and the door closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Four Fitness Facts to Fuel Your Workout
description: Things to keep in mind for when you’re low on motivation.
content: There’s rarely enough time in the day to accomplish everything we set out to do, and exercise is often sacrificed when we’re short on time. Federal guidelines recommend fitting two and a half hours of moderate physical activity into our lives each week — and making time for muscle-strengthening exercises.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Thatched-Roof Huts on Lake Kivu, Rwanda
description: Plus: a green hotel in Paris, a Standard in Bangkok and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Tomato Mode
description: Fresh summer tomatoes lend themselves beautifully to some exceptional no-cook and low-cook meals.
content: I’m in full tomato mode, a phrase I saw tweeted this week by the excellent New York magazine food reporter Chris Crowley that tracks closely with my current state of mind. I’m going wild at the market, buying all manner of tomatoes, arranging them on my counter with reverence and then eating them as though I’ve joined a religious order devoted to this one particular, highly seasonal food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: Getting Well With Lori Leibovich
description: The editor of Well shares why she tries to be a stand-in for readers when she is editing, and how the desk is diving deep into mental health.
content: One might think that Lori Leibovich, the editor of the Well desk at The New York Times, has an ultra-rigorous wellness regimen. In reality, Ms. Leibovich approaches her health just like most Times readers do. “I don’t have some crazy fitness routine, and I’m not taking fistfuls of supplements,” she said in a recent interview. “I just feel worse when I don’t take good care of myself.” For Ms. Leibovich, that means going for walks and meditating for 10 minutes a day — what she calls her “non-negotiables.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Blinken Resists Push to Label Russia a Terrorist State
description: The Biden administration is wary of making the designation despite strong calls from Congress and pleas from Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate supports it unanimously. So does House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, along with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, and the Ukrainian Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Photos That Helped to Document the Holocaust Were Taken by a Nazi
description: Historians have relied on Herman Heukels’s pictures of Jewish persecution in World War II, but it’s not widely known that the Dutch photographer shot them as Nazi propaganda.
content: AMSTERDAM — On June 20, 1943, bewildered and terrified families, laden with baggage and branded with yellow stars, were forced into Olympiaplein, one of this city’s most recognizable public squares. Few knew where they were going, or for how long, so they wore their winter coats despite the blazing sun as they registered with the Nazi authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Melanie Metz
title: Mom Knows Best. She Fights Best, Too.
description: Years ago, the U.F.C. excluded women. The contestants in Saturday’s title bout, Julianna Peña and Amanda Nunes, are proud to be fighters and mothers.
content: In 2011, Dana White, the president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, said women would never fight in the promotion. He had seen a women’s fight in Northern California that was poorly matched, and the loser suffered a bashing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Small Business Owners Are Still Struggling in New York
description: “I feel like it’s 50-50,” said the owner of a Brooklyn coffee shop who is finding it hard to rebound from the pandemic.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how small businesses are holding up as the city tries to move out of the pandemic. We’ll go kayaking with a congressional hopeful who is one of more than a dozen Democrats running in the Aug. 23 primary in just one district. And, speaking of the primary, today is the last day to register to vote in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Bottom of the Ocean,’ a Deep Dive Into the Soul
description: Themes of change, death and rebirth abound in this peculiar production, a triumph of style and low-budget ingenuity.
content: A spa day, a sound bath, a moving meditation and an initiation into strange and tentacled rites, “Bottom of the Ocean,” an immersive experience staged in a semifinished Brooklyn basement, ranks as the weirdest show in town right now, in a town that doesn’t lack for weird. How odd is it? Show me another work that hides baby octopuses (yes, OK, fake baby octopuses) in its communal bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: In Compromise, the Climate Left May Be Vindicated
description: The Manchin-Schumer bill may well prove inadequate. It also represents a generational achievement.
content: The deal, if it holds, is very big, several times as large as anything on climate the United States passed into law before. The architects and supporters of the $369 billion in climate and clean-energy provisions in Joe Manchin’s Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, announced Wednesday, are already calculating that it could reduce American carbon emissions by 40 percent, compared with 2005 levels, by 2030. That’s close enough to President Biden’s pledge of 50 percent that exhausted advocates seem prepared to count it as a victory, if a somewhat mixed one that still falls short of the demands of scientists and the Paris Agreement. But hundreds of billions in spending and hundreds of billions more in loans do add up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Khalid Abdulqaadir
title: The Polygraph Test That Saved My Marriage
description: What a terrifying relief it was to have to tell the truth about everything.
content: “Have you ever kept a secret from your wife?” asked the polygraph examiner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Harris
title: 6 Ways You’re Coping With a Roller-Coaster Market
description: Readers from around the world shared their strategies for protecting their retirement savings and how, or if, they’re adjusting their tactics.
content: We measure the health of the economy as a whole by a few big numbers — interest rates, which the Federal Reserve raised by three-quarters of a point on Wednesday; gross domestic product, which we learned on Thursday had dropped for a second consecutive quarter; and the stock market, which has been bouncing around for months. But for people working toward retirement, or dreaming of it, the one number that matters most is closer to home: their own retirement savings. And the volatility in the big-picture numbers is connected, of course, to individual plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: A Paean to the Gods (and Shammgods) of New York City Hoops
description: Some of the most memorable characters in New York basketball history gathered in Manhattan for a screening of the documentary film “NYC Point Gods,” a tribute to — well, to them.
content: There is little left that defines New York City basketball, save for the Knicks’ eternal search for an impactful lead guard. It’s a search that has always been inflamed, exacerbated and magnified by the abundance of point guards bred by the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Three Pressing Questions About Monkeypox: Spread, Vaccination, Treatment
description: Containing the outbreak, scientists say, will depend on better understanding the virus’s transmission and how well available tools work.
content: Monkeypox, once a relatively obscure virus endemic to Africa, has bloomed into a global threat, infecting more than 20,000 people in 75 countries and forcing the World Health Organization to declare a worldwide health emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Prisoner Said He Was Waterboarded; Agents Omitted It From Memo
description: The revelation came in the latest pretrial hearings in the long-running U.S.S. Cole bombing case.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A prisoner accused of plotting Al Qaeda’s bombing of the U.S.S. Cole warship in 2000 told federal interrogators years later that he was waterboarded by the C.I.A., an interpreter testified this week. But that detail was omitted from the official account of the interrogations that prosecutors want to use at his death-penalty trial as evidence that he confessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Maya King
title: Democrats’ Plan to Win in 2022 Looks a Lot Like 2020 and 2018
description: Stacey Abrams is again providing a blueprint for national Democrats to follow. But can it work at a time of deep unhappiness with Washington?
content: Today’s newsletter is a guest dispatch from Georgia, where my colleague Maya King covers politics across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Will Anyone Hold Daniel Snyder Accountable?
description: Snyder, the Washington Commanders’ owner, finally appeared before a congressional committee investigating his team’s workplace culture. But he did it remotely, and without the spotlight of live TV.
content: Who is going to hold Daniel Snyder accountable for his misdeeds?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a buoyant queer romance from Germany, a Malayalam-language mafia thriller and a South African horror flick.
content: If you’re looking to watch something off the beaten streaming path this week, take a scroll through “New Directions: 20 Years of Young German Cinema,” a free online series hosted by The Goethe-Institut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: More rainfall is expected across the region on Friday.
description: A flood watch was in effect for parts of Kentucky and West Virginia.
content: More rounds of excessive rainfall across parts of the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys were expected to trigger flash flooding throughout Friday, according to the Weather Prediction Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What Psychologists Want Today’s Young Adults to Know
description: The generation entering adulthood now faces novel, sometimes debilitating, challenges. Experts offer tools to navigate a “quarterlife crisis.”
content: Satya Doyle Byock, a 39-year-old therapist, noticed a shift in tone over the past few years in the young people who streamed into her office: frenetic, frazzled clients in their late teens, 20s and 30s. They were unnerved and unmoored, constantly feeling like something was wrong with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: The M.T.A. Is Bringing Cellphone Service to New York’s Subway Tunnels
description: The project will come at no public cost but will take 10 years to finish.
content: New York City’s subway tunnels, among just a handful of places in the sprawling metropolis where cellphone service remains out of reach, will be wired to connect riders traveling underground, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: In Brooklyn, Her Champagne Wishes Came True
description: For decades, Marvina Robinson dreamed of creating a champagne label and a place to sip it. After debuting her B. Stuyvesant Champagne brand in 2020, she opened a tasting space in June at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
content: Marvina Robinson fell in love with champagne as a “broke college student,” when she and her friends would scrape together enough money to buy a bottle or two, for no particular reason, except to enjoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: Watch the Southern Delta Aquariid Meteor Shower Peak in Night Skies
description: Fireballs may light up the sky for those willing to stay up late and take in the show.
content: Friday night into Saturday morning will be one of the special dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower as a multitude of flares potentially burst in the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon craft a self-affirming puzzle.
content: So ACROSTIC — Solving this puzzle was a bit like struggling along a steep, rocky path up a mountain to discover a famous writer at its peak, without a hair out of place, describing how pleasurable and easy his hike was on exactly the same route. But I survived and learned of Isaac Asimov’s affinity for acrostics, or “crostics,” as described in “Yours, Isaac Asimov: A Lifetime in Letters,” the source of this passage. This is a collection culled from Asimov’s voluminous correspondence: In his lifetime, he apparently received more than 100,000 letters and answered over 90 percent of them. I imagine that more than one fan asked about the writer’s hobbies; that sounds like the likely genesis of this excerpt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Will Smith Says He Is ‘Deeply Remorseful’ Over Chris Rock Slap
description: In an apologetic video, Mr. Smith addressed questions over his behavior at the Oscars, which resulted in a 10-year ban from the ceremony.
content: Four months after slapping the comedian Chris Rock at the Oscars, shocking audiences and prompting a decade-long ban from attending the ceremony, Will Smith posted a video on Friday expressing regret over the incident and promising that he was doing “personal work” to address his behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Can’t Believe ‘Joe Manchin Is Fighting Climate Change’
description: “Wait, am I dreaming? I have all my teeth, I’m not a skeleton, you’re all wearing clothes, I’m rich and famous — no, this is real,” Colbert joked.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Stuart Woods, Prolific Best-Selling Thriller Author, Dies at 84
description: His mysteries featured extravagant characters like Stone Barrington, a libidinous New York lawyer who, like Mr. Woods, hung out at Elaine’s.
content: Stuart Woods, a prolific, prizewinning mystery writer who churned out multiple best sellers during what his memoir duly described as “an extravagant life,” died on July 22 at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Behind the Story: The Bridge Los Angeles Loves Too Much
description: The new Sixth Street Viaduct in Los Angeles has become a target for graffiti artists and exhibitionist drivers.
content: LOS ANGELES — A couple grinned at each other as they glided on bicycles across this city’s newest landmark, a glistening concrete bridge that connects the downtown arts district to the working class neighborhood of Boyle Heights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Review: A ‘Tristan und Isolde’ Plays Out in Shadows and Light
description: At Santa Fe Opera, Wagner’s work is being presented for the first time, in a striking, modest staging that makes space for the music.
content: SANTA FE, N.M. — The play of light has always been part of the show at the Santa Fe Opera: its majestic, open-sided theater in the foothills making drama out of the darkening of the sky and the brightening of the stars, even the flash of a hopefully distant storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Here is how to help victims of the flooding in Kentucky.
description: Many organizations are collecting monetary donations and supplies for victims of the flooding.
content: Search-and-rescue efforts continued across much of southeastern Kentucky on Friday after what Gov. Andy Beshear said was “one of the worst, most devastating flooding events” ever to hit the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: Pacific Northwest Restaurants Struggle as Temperatures Spike
description: Punishing heat has owners closing early, canceling outdoor dining and wondering about their future in a region where air-conditioning is not the norm.
content: On Wednesday, the temperature in the tight kitchen at Blotto, a pizza restaurant in Seattle, reached 108 degrees. Like many restaurants in the city, Blotto does not have air-conditioning. Facing due west, it gets hours of the summer-afternoon sunlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Charlotte Pomerantz, Inventive Children’s Book Author, Dies at 92
description: Her imaginative use of words and lively rhymes entertained young readers, sometimes with a subtle message included, drawn from her own life.
content: Charlotte Pomerantz, who brought an ingenious use of language and the occasional sly subversive touch to stories about mud-loving pigs and parachuting cats written for young children, died on Sunday at her home in Charlottesville, Va. It was her 92nd birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli
title: Beyoncé Unveils ‘Renaissance,’ the First of Three New Projects
description: The pop star’s seventh solo album is “Act I” of work born during the pandemic, a time she “found to be the most creative,” she said in a statement.
content: The new Beyoncé album has officially arrived. In a rare breach of the pop queen’s carefully choreographed release plans, an unauthorized version of “Renaissance,” the singer’s seventh solo studio LP and the first part of a teased trilogy, leaked two days early online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Coming This Season: Pep Guardiola 3.0
description: Manchester City will begin defense of its Premier League title with a team that doesn’t (exactly) look like its predecessors. That isn’t necessarily a bad thing.
content: Two months on, the euphoria has not yet faded. A few days ago, with the rich promise of a new season drifting into view, Manchester City released “Together: Champions Again,” an official documentary detailing the thrilling, triumphant journey that culminated in Pep Guardiola’s team lifting yet another Premier League trophy last May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: Investing in Real Estate as Self-Care
description: Many women seeking independence after a breakup or divorce have discovered emotional empowerment and even healing in real estate investment.
content: Richelle DeVoe was two weeks shy of closing on a house with her partner of 10 years, when their relationship imploded. Her future suddenly snapped into focus: She was 30 and had a successful career as a marketing strategist, but she’d never feel truly secure without a permanent roof over her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Pressure Grows in the U.S. for the U.A.E. to Free an American Lawyer
description: Asim Ghafoor once represented the Saudi dissident and columnist Jamal Khashoggi, who was murdered in 2018 by Saudi agents. He was arrested this month in Dubai.
content: Pressure is mounting in the United States for the United Arab Emirates to release a Virginia lawyer who represented Jamal Khashoggi, the Saudi dissident and Washington Post columnist who was murdered and dismembered by Saudi agents in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: St. Louis flooded again after more rain.
description: The St. Louis Fire Department said it responded to 75 flood-related emergencies on Thursday, two days after up to a foot of rain inundated the region’s interstates and neighborhoods.
content: Two days after flash flooding hit the St. Louis area, breaking a century-old rainfall record, the region was hit with another round of storms that caused more flooding, requiring dozens of residents to be rescued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Doug Mills
title: At a LIV Golf Event, Thin Crowds and a Tense Start
description: The controversy over the new golf series, which is backed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, isn’t going away. But on the course, fans enjoyed the easygoing camaraderie among the players.
content: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Standing over his ball on Friday, Phil Mickelson, the prized acquisition of the new, Saudi-backed LIV Golf series, lined up his opening tee shot in the breakaway circuit’s event at Trump National Golf Club Bedminster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Wine Connoisseurs, in Coupling, Discover the Perfect Blend
description: Anthony Zraly and Keith Henderson met while working for a Manhattan wine distributor and bonded over their love of food, spirits and European house music.
content: Anthony Zraly was signing paperwork on his first day of a sales job at T. Edward Wines and Spirits in Manhattan, in January 2019, when he noticed David Keith Henderson sitting at a nearby desk. Hoping to get the attention of Mr. Henderson, who goes by Keith, Mr. Zraly started speaking loudly about his interests, including his affinity for long trail runs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lou Stoppard and Katherine Rosman
title: ‘Wagatha Christie’ Trial, a British Spectacle, Ends: Judge Finds No Libel
description: The High Court in London ruled against the plaintiff, Rebekah Vardy, putting an end to a social media feud that turned into a high-profile legal face-off.
content: LONDON — It began as an Instagram-related quarrel between the spouses of two British soccer stars and grew into a libel trial that provided a welcome distraction for a nation in turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Eurozone Economy Grew Faster Than Expected, but So Did Prices
description: Inflation in countries that use the euro increased to 8.9 percent in July, another record fueled by energy prices, as the bloc’s economy expanded 0.7 percent in the second quarter.
content: Consumer prices driven by the soaring cost of energy continued to take a toll on Europe, causing growth in the continent’s traditional engine, Germany, to stall even as other large economies grew faster than expected, data released on Friday showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia’s foreign minister says he will propose a time for a phone call about a prisoner exchange.
description: Sergey Lavrov said he would listen to what U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had to say about a proposal for the release of Brittney Griner and another American.
content: Russia’s foreign minister said on Friday that he would propose a convenient date for a phone call with Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken to discuss a possible prisoner exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: The $1.28 Billion Mega Millions Jackpot and You
description: On Friday night, these were the winning numbers: 67, 45, 57, 36, 13 and the Mega Ball, 14. Here’s what else you need to know.
content: The Mega Millions jackpot ballooned to $1.28 billion this week, making it the lottery’s second-largest prize since it began in 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Why Catholicism Remains Strong in Canada
description: Even as Catholicism wanes in many Western countries, in Canada, it is holding steady as the largest religious denomination.
content: EDMONTON, Alberta — The centerpiece of ​Pope Francis​’s journey to Canada this week ​was his historic message o​f apology on Monday ​to ​the country’s ​Indigenous people​ for the Catholic Church’s role in the notorious residential school system that tried to erase their culture, and in which thousands of children were abused and died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: China Has Leapfrogged the U.S. in Key Technologies. Can a New Law Help?
description: While Congress argued over whether and how to support American chip makers and research in other technologies, China was surging ahead.
content: In the weeks before the House and the Senate ended 13 months of arguments and passed the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, China’s main, state-supported chip maker cleared a major technological hurdle that delivered a bit of a shock to the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices Sotomayor and Barrett Say the Supreme Court Remains Collegial
description: In an appearance recorded 10 days after the draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade was leaked in May, both maintained that relations on the court were warm and respectful.
content: WASHINGTON — Two members of the Supreme Court, one liberal and the other conservative, insisted during a joint interview made public on Thursday that relations among the justices remained warm and respectful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Not Searching for Love, They Found It at Google
description: When Mrinal Kalakrishnan and Preeti Talwai first met at work, neither of them was looking for romance. Several months later, they went on their first date.
content: In the summer of 2017, Mrinal Kalakrishnan and Preeti Murali Talwai arrived at a crossroads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: How a Sushi Chef Spends His Sundays
description: After a morning swim, Nozomu Abe starts menu planning and negotiating with his fish broker.
content: Nozomu Abe, the renowned sushi chef, remembers telling his family in elementary school that he wanted to make pizza for a living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Despite Biden’s Success on Judges, Progressives Demand a Faster Pace
description: Democrats may leave dozens of federal judicial vacancies unfilled this year, prompting concern among liberal groups about a blockade should Republicans win the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — With an extended summer recess looming and their majority at risk in November elections, Senate Democrats were facing the prospect of allowing dozens of judicial vacancies to go unfilled by President Biden this year, and under pressure from progressive activists to move more quickly and aggressively to push them through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: The Fight to Save New York’s Extravagantly ’80s Subway Entrance
description: The throwback atrium at 60 Wall Street — which also provides access to the subway — has its fans, but its future is unclear.
content: Angular white columns. Dizzying mirrored tile. Lines of palm trees. The atrium at 60 Wall Street, which is also one of New York’s most distinctive subway entrances, feels to some “like stepping back in time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Fox News, Once Home to Trump, Now Often Ignores Him
description: The former president hasn’t been interviewed on the Rupert Murdoch-owned cable network in more than 100 days, and other Republicans often get the attention he once did.
content: It’s been more than 100 days since Donald J. Trump was interviewed on Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Allergan Reaches Tentative $2.37 Billion Deal to Settle Opioid Suits
description: If finalized, the agreement, along with a companion deal reached by Teva earlier this week, would send as much as $6.6 billion to communities harmed by the opioid epidemic.
content: A bipartisan group of state attorneys general announced Friday morning that it had struck an agreement in principle with the pharmaceutical company Allergan for $2.37 billion to resolve more than 2,500 opioid-related lawsuits brought by states, local governments and tribes nationwide who have suffered during the ongoing opioid epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Explosion Kills Dozens of Ukrainian Captives at Russian-Held Prison
description: At least 50 captured fighters died in a blast at a prison in eastern Ukraine, with no clarity on exactly what happened and each country blaming the other.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — For the Russians, the Ukrainian fighters held prisoner at Correctional Colony No. 120 are a trophy. For the Ukrainians, they are war heroes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Parechovirus Sickened 23 Infants in Nashville, C.D.C. Says
description: The common pathogen frequently produces the mild symptoms of a cold, but it can cause severe illness and death in babies under 3 months old, health officials say, warning doctors to be vigilant.
content: Over six weeks this spring, 23 children were admitted to a Tennessee hospital for treatment of parechovirus, a common virus that in rare cases can a pose a lethal threat to infants, according to a report released this week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmytro Kuleba
title: I’m Ukraine’s Foreign Minister. Putin Must Be Stopped.
description: Now is not the time to accept unfavorable cease-fire proposals.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia, apparently, is ready for a cease-fire. The door to negotiations, the Kremlin’s spokesman said last week, has never been closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Recession? Not for Big Tech.
description: Many companies are navigating tough times better than investors had feared.
content: When the president, the treasury secretary and other Biden administration officials insisted this week that the American economy is not currently in a recession, they were mocked for weaseling out of bad news on a technicality. The Commerce Department announced on Thursday that the broadest measure of economic activity, gross domestic product, fell for a second quarter in a row — meeting a widely held, though unofficial, definition of recession. It is true, as the Biden folks argued, that the nation’s official recession arbiter, the National Bureau of Economic Research, has yet to call one, because it relies on many more signals. Still, it sure sounded as if the Biden team was splitting hairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Exxon and Chevron Report Record Profits on High Oil and Gas Prices
description: The energy industry’s windfall followed a spike in prices, resulting mostly from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the global economic rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest energy companies in the United States, said on Friday that profits rose to record levels in the second quarter as they continued to reap the benefits of soaring oil and gas prices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Monkeypox, Gay Men Confront a Health Crisis With Echoes of the Past
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 29, 2022.
content: “We have been forced to fight for our own health care when we got let down by the government. Shame on the government for letting us down again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daphne Merkin
title: The Enduring Appeal of Moral Monsters
description: For “The Hangman and His Wife,” her biography of the prominent Nazi Reinhard Heydrich, Nancy Dougherty interviewed his widow.
content: What is the fatal attraction they exert on us, the Nazis? We continue to read books and watch documentaries about them many decades after they coolly commenced upon exterminating the Jews — a genocide that in terms of its duration and thoroughness remains unparalleled in the bloody annals of history. (A close instance would probably be the extermination of the Armenians by the Turks during World War I, about which Hitler said, in one of his incendiary speeches: “Who, after all, speaks today of the annihilation of the Armenians?”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Kashmir Hill
title: How Streaming Stars Pay the Price of Online Fame
description: Stars on Twitch, the video game streaming platform, invite viewers into their homes virtually. What happens when one shows up in person?
content: The unwanted visitor rapped on Kaitlyn Siragusa’s front door and peered through the windows of her home on the outskirts of Houston. When she did not answer, he walked around to the back of her house and jiggled a doorknob there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Living Without Air-Conditioning? Here’s How to Stay Cooler at Home.
description: Adjust your ceiling fans to rotate counterclockwise, run major appliances at night and consider planting trees to shade your home, multiple governments suggest.
content: Scorching temperatures at the height of summer often surpass 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 Celsius) for days and even weeks at a time across many parts of the globe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Ride Out a Murky Economy
description: Rates are rising, inflation is nasty and a painful recession is certainly possible. But there are steps you can take now, our columnist says.
content: Important pieces of information arrived over the last few days, but they do nothing to clear away the fog blanketing the markets and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Biden’s Vaccine Plan for Fall
description: And a look at the postpandemic economy.
content: The Biden administration is planning to distribute vaccines that have been retooled to fight Omicron in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: A Disputed Blast Kills P.O.W.s
description: Russia and Ukraine accuse each other of committing a war crime.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Nina Feldman, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Eric Krupke, Patricia Willens, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Rise of the Conservative Latina
description: Representative Mayra Flores is one of three Republican Latinas vying to transform South Texas politics — often by embracing the extreme.
content: For decades, Republicans have sought to make gains with a critical voting block: Latinos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Beating of Teen by Illinois Police Is Captured on Video
description: The Oak Lawn Police Department said that the boy, identified by his lawyer as 17-year-old Hadi Abuatelah, was armed with a semiautomatic handgun and ran from officers during a traffic stop.
content: A 17-year-old boy who was seen on video being beaten by police officers in Oak Lawn, south of Chicago, was hospitalized with a broken nose and bleeding near his brain, family representatives said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Second day of heavy rain leads to flash flooding in Las Vegas.
description: The downpour dumped about half the area’s annual rainfall. Rainwater leaked into some casinos.
content: Monsoonal rains and thunderstorms overtook Las Vegas on Thursday evening for the second night in a row, causing flash flooding that turned parts of the Strip into rivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Redistricting Caused Chaos. Some Savvy Politicians Are Making the Most of It.
description: With only a month before the primary, a Bronx progressive packed her bags and headed upstate with the aim of taking on another Democrat who also switched districts.
content: On Wednesday afternoon, when I reached her by phone, State Senator Alessandra Biaggi was making her way from the Bronx River Parkway to the Saw Mill, in the midst of a move to her new home about 10 miles north of White Plains. “I’m literally on the way,” she told me. “I’m not even kidding.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: On the Set of ‘Law & Order: SVU,’ an Unscripted Meet Cute
description: After the actors Terry Serpico and Kadia Saraf filmed their first “Law & Order: SVU” scene, Mr. Serpico resorted to note-passing — and contacting Ms. Saraf’s manager — to continue their conversation.
content: To express his interest in Kadia Saraf after meeting her on the set of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” Terry Serpico resorted to a grade school tactic: passing Ms. Saraf a note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Jesus Jiménez
title: Kentucky’s governor said the death toll from the flooding included children.
description: Andy Beshear said he expected the number of dead to rise further after heavy rain and severe flooding.
content: The death toll in the devastating flash floods that hit Kentucky this week climbed to at least 25 on Friday, according to updated figures released Friday night by the governor’s office and the local authorities. And the number was expected to keep rising as rescue efforts continued in the eastern region of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: All thrills, no filler this week. You want smuggling, you want entrapment, you want murder? Check, check, check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Future of Food
description: How the agriculture industry could go from farming to “ferming.”
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Why Andrew Yang’s New Third Party Is Bound to Fail
description: You can’t take the conflict out of politics. Nor should you want to.
content: Let’s not mince words. The new Forward Party announced by the former presidential candidate Andrew Yang, the former governor Christine Todd Whitman and the former congressman David Jolly is doomed to failure. The odds that it will attract any more than a token amount of support from the public, not to mention political elites, are slim to none. It will wither on the vine as the latest in a long history of vanity political parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Tsui
title: Water Dance
description: Two picture books and a graphic novel treat swimming as an expansive state of being, slippery with promise.
content: “What do you think about when you think about swimming?” I asked this recently of a classroom of high school students, and though their answers ranged widely — “fun,” “a little bit of fear,” “family,” “summer” — one answer led the pack: “freedom.” I love that our human relationship with water spurs conversations about so much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Rotunno
title: Love Letter: Would a Polygraph Test Save Your Marriage?
description: Plus, an unscripted meet cute on the set of “Law & Order: SVU.”
content: The query came as Khalid Abdulqaadir was taking a polygraph test to obtain security clearance for a U.S. government intelligence agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Purple Hearts’ Review: A Marriage of Convenience
description: Netflix’s romantic drama, featuring the Disney-minted star Sofia Carson, follows a Marine and a musician who wed out of financial desperation.
content: The romantic Netflix drama “Purple Hearts” tries to wring a heartfelt story from an arrangement that can’t help but feel absurd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Julian E. Barnes
title: House Passes Assault Weapons Ban That Is Doomed in Senate
description: Coming on the heels of a spate of mass shootings, the vote gave Democrats another opportunity to draw a sharp distinction with Republicans before the midterm elections.
content: WASHINGTON — Responding to a string of mass shootings, a divided House passed a ban on assault weapons on Friday, moving over the near-unanimous opposition of Republicans to reinstate a prohibition that expired nearly two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Their Courtship in a Nutshell? Cry and Cry Again.
description: When Hunter Davis asked Kara Naseef out on a first date, both were overcome with emotion. The same thing happened three years later when Ms. Davis proposed.
content: Hunter Davis didn’t think it was at all weird that Kara Naseef cried when Ms. Davis asked her out on a first date in March 2017. Ms. Davis, too, was close to tears. “I had never asked anyone out,” she said. “I was scared.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
description: This week, the late-night hosts discussed monkeypox, the end of the Choco Taco and more.
content: This week, the late-night hosts discussed monkeypox, the end of the Choco Taco and more.

content: The case of the $5,000 Bruce Springsteen tickets. Also in this edition: the hounds guarding U.S. agriculture, and why Pilates is having a moment.

content: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Robert Icke's production of "Oresteia" at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Watch Live: Kentucky Officials Give an Update on Severe Flooding
description: Officials provide an update on the deadly flash floods that have hit Kentucky as more rain is expected in the region.
content: Officials provide an update on the deadly flash floods that have hit Kentucky as more rain is expected in the region.

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: Flash Floods Hit Las Vegas Casinos
description: Up to an inch of rain fell in Las Vegas in about two hours, causing flash floods along the city’s famous Strip.
content: Up to an inch of rain fell in Las Vegas in about two hours, causing flash floods along the city’s famous Strip.

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Reintroducing Sam Sanders
description: After 12 years at NPR, the former host of “It’s Been a Minute” is stepping out with a new pop culture podcast — uncensored, uninhibited and unbothered.
content: The chocolate rum notwithstanding, Sam Sanders was full of good spirits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: No matter how you make it, it’s always good with tortilla chips for scooping.
content: Good morning. Helen Corbitt was a dietitian from New York who moved to Texas in 1931 to manage the tearoom at the University of Texas at Austin. She went on to work at the Houston Country Club, and for years as the director of food services at the Neiman Marcus department store in Dallas. When she died in 1978, at 71, after more than 45 years in the state, she left behind a legacy of cookbooks and recipes that led Texas Monthly to name her the state’s Tastemaker of the Century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: J. Lo, J. Aff and Women’s Choices
description: A star, a marriage and a new name. Also: Congress and the climate; the learning gap; President Biden and Ukraine.

title: Corrections: July 29, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 29, 2022.
content: An article on July 22 about the sentencing of a former Minneapolis police officer who held down George Floyd’s legs included an outdated reference to the upcoming state trial of two other officers, J. Alexander Kueng and Tou Thao. It is now scheduled to begin in October, not in January.
source.name: The New York Times
